content.text: You are provided with a T-shaped card. The card has a mark on it and 14 holes
Label the holes on the card, 1 to 14, starting from the top end as shown in Fig. 1.1
Set up the apparatus, placing the pin through hole number 9, as shown in Fig. 1.2
Fig. 1.2
Measure and record the distance \(h\) between the pin and the mark
Displace the card shape to the left. Release the shape and watch its movement
The shape will move to the right and then to the left again, completing a swing as shown in Fig. 1.3
Measure and record the time for at least 10 swings
Record enough readings to determine an accurate value for the time \(T\) taken for one complete swing
Vary \(h\), by changing the hole through which the pin is placed, and repeat **(b)(ii)** and **(c)** until you have six sets of values of \(h\) and \(T\)
For
Examiner's
Use
Include values of \(T^2 h\) and \(h^2\) in your table
Plot a graph of \(T^2 h\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(h^2\) on the \(x\)-axis
Draw the straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line
gradient =
y-intercept =

where \(P\) and \(Q\) are constants

In this experiment, you will investigate how the motion of a thin card shape depends on where the shape is supported
Record the mass \(m\) of the model. This information is given on the card
Measure and record the total length \(L\) of the model, as shown in Fig. 2.1
Fig. 2.1
Support the board as shown in Fig. 2.2
Fig. 2.2
Place the back wheels of the model on the line. This is position A
Release the model. It travels a distance of \(40\mathrm{cm}\) down the board until all the wheels are on the bench. This is position B
The model moves a distance along the bench before stopping. This is position C
Distance \(s\) is measured from the end of the board to the front of the model as shown in Fig. 2.2
Repeat **(b)**(i) until \(s\) is approximately \(60\mathrm{cm}\)
It may be necessary to adjust the slope of the board before releasing the model
Do not adjust the slope of the board throughout the remainder of the experiment
Measure and record the distance \(s\)
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(s\)
percentage uncertainty =   .........
Use your values from **(a)**(ii) and **(b)**(ii) to determine the distance \(x\) moved by the model between B and C, where
Replace the model at A
Release the model
Measure and record the time \(t\) taken to move from B to C and the distance \(s\)
Calculate \(x\)
t =
s =
x =
Calculate the average speed \(v\) of the model between B and C using the relationship
Justify the number of significant figures that you have given for your value of \(v\)
Fix the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass on top of the model using the Blu-Tack
Calculate and record the total mass \(M\) of the model and the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass
Repeat (c) and (d)(i)
t =

It is suggested that \(v\) remains constant when \(M\) is changed
Explain whether your results support the suggested relationship
Describe four sources of uncertainty or limitations of the procedure for this experiment
Describe four improvements that could be made to this experiment. You may suggest the use of other apparatus or different procedures
You may not need to use all of the materials provided
In this experiment, you will investigate how the stopping distance of a model vehicle depends on its mass
